awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Gate City Research Network - A Multi-Institution Science DMZ
awd_abstract_narration:
The Gate City Research Network (GCRN) is a collaboration between the University of North Carolina at Greensboro (UNCG) and North Carolina A&T State University (NC A&T) to create a multi-institutional science DMZ supporting research activities through a dedicated, low-latency, high-speed research and education network connection. The GCRN enhances researcher access to high performance computing (HPC) resources supporting the competitive and innovative research environment state-wide and regionally by connecting the Southeastern Nanotechnology Infrastructure Corridor through the Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering (JSNN).

The GCRN, connected to the North Carolina Research and Education Network and Internet2, provides a dedicated, separate research network to overcome the latency challenges imposed on the enterprise networks that support the administrative and growing entertainment service traffic. The addition of a high-speed data transfer node facilitates fast transfers of large data to federated HPC environments at partner institutions and provides the foundation to enhance the end-to-end data flow processes from research instrumentation to analysis, simulation and modeling computational resources, significantly increasing the fundamental research capacity in disciplines such as chemistry, nano-engineering, nano-, computer-, and data science. The GCRN is committed to producing open access design, sustainability and governance documentation, use and performance data, and testing and operations protocols in support of developing a  21st-century data capable workforce and serving as a model for a scalable and efficient  multi-institutional science DMZ.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Gate City Research Network (gcrNet) is a unique, multi-institution science DMZ collaboration between the University of North Carolina at Greensboro (UNCG) and North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) serving the Piedmont Triad region. gcrNet advances research and educational missions of UNCG, NCA&T and the Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering (JSNN) by providing researchers a dedicated high-speed network leveraging existing large-scale, jointly-owned 11-mile fiber ring. gcrNet provides clean, low-latency, high-speed internet connection solely for shuttling data gathered through scientific equipment on site to partner institution HPCs using a high-speed data transfer node. gcrNet enables researchers to collaborate externally on large data sets without the associated negative impacts of enterprise and entertainment bandwidth.

The network was designed in consultation with the Engagement and Performance Operations Center (EPOC), a collaboration between the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) and the Energy Sciences Network (ESnet). Following guidelines from Energy Science Network (ESNet) for a Science DMZ, gcrNet leverages its own dedicated 10G connection (100Gb capable) to North Carolina?s National Research and Education Network (NCREN) operated by MCNC (https://www.mcnc.org/), segregating research traffic from commodity university traffic. gcrNet is the first IPv6-native based network for the institutions involved providing network engineers valuable experience with IPv6 deployments . A Globus Data Transfer Node (DTN), another first, was added to facilitate easy and high speed transfers of large data sets from local instrumentation to compute resources at national laboratories previously scene as unobtainable for UNCG, NCA&T, and JSNN researchers.

gcrNet was installed on UNCG main campus with access layers extended to its science buildings, the Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering located at the south campus of Gateway Research Park housing many scientific instruments for data collection, and at NCA&T's main campus with capability to reach its science buildings. Initial network testing began in mid-2021 with PerfSonar monitoring nodes installed at each of the three campuses. Using the completed DTN and storage design, the network and internet link was tested with 9.22GBps throughput and 0% loss between gcrNet and partner institution UNC Chapel Hill. 

gcrNet incurred significant setbacks due to the COVID-19 global pandemic. First, delays were incurred in obtaining necessary network and server hardware during supply chain shortages. Secondly, the mandates to work remotely impacted the institutions involved by delaying the ability to be on site for installation and configuration. Finally, staff turnover at all institutions not only delayed the technical team but research faculty and research projects originally slated to be science drivers leveraging gcrNet. Nevertheless, the gcrNet has been installed and operationally tested confirming its design and is available to support future plans to implement the science drivers identified to exercise the network.
